awd_titl_txt: Children's real-time language processing and verb learning during interactions with caregivers
awd_abstract_narration:
Learning language is one of the most fundamental tasks children face in the first few years of life. Children who struggle with this task are at higher risk of experiencing difficulties in school, as well as challenges at work and in relationships with loved ones and in the community. A key factor in successful language learning is the richness of the language children hear from their caregivers. To understand why some children develop strong language skills and others do not, it is essential to understand how caregivers adapt their language to match their child's needs and abilities. This project will study how caregivers adapt their language when introducing new words to their children, and how this affects the way children learn the words. This project will also train students, teachers, and parents to better understand child language learning.

The experiments in this project are based on a game that caregivers and children play together. The game allows researchers to test how quickly and how well children discover the meanings of new words. The children who participate in this research will be 2-, 3-, and 4-year-old children acquiring English as their first language. The research team will measure children's language comprehension and language learning using state-of-the-art eye-tracking techniques. This technique involves showing children several pictures, one of which their caregiver describes using a word that is unfamiliar to the child, and then analyzing whether and how quickly children direct their gaze to the correct picture as it described. These data will reveal what features of caregiver speech best support children's language comprehension and learning of the unfamiliar word. Results of the research will be shared with other child language researchers and will also be used to create easy-to-use educational materials that will give parents and teachers strategies for supporting children in their language learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was threefold: (1) to understand how English-learning children aged 2 to 4 years learn the meanings of new words by hearing them in context, (2) to understand how parents adjust the contexts they use to best support children in this endeavor, and (3) to increase public knowledge about child language development—primarily parents in our community, but also students and other aspiring researchers who assist with the project.

 

With respect to our first goal, we learned that young children are quite adept at making guesses about what a new word means by hearing it in sentences, but that these sentences cannot be overly complex because children face limitations in how much information they can process. As children get older, their abilities to process information increase, as do their abilities to benefit from a wider variety of sentence contexts. Our findings have implications for theories of language development, because we were able to integrate research on vocabulary learning with research on real-time language processing to identify ways in which learning skills and processing demands interact. The findings not only identify both information and processing load as two key components that determine a child's ability to learn new words from sentence contexts, but will also help us make predictions about what kinds of sentences will best support children's learning. The findings may also have implications for clinical practice, because interventions for children who are struggling to acquire language have to present vocabulary words in sentences, and our research provides guidance for thinking about what kinds of sentences might work best.

 

With respect to our second goal, we found that parents are sensitive to their child’s language abilities and they tailor the contexts they use accordingly. These findings are consistent with previous research and theoretical perspectives arguing that parents’ language is tuned to their child, but it expands those findings to new contexts. These findings may also have implications for clinical practice; parents may be a useful source of information for professional clinicians to use in thinking about how best to support a child’s language.

 

With respect to our third goal, we gave over 10 presentations to parent groups about child language; created short videos about child language development in partnership with a local artist, Tamisha Anthony, which have received over 1,000 views on YouTube; and trained over 16 scholars in how to conduct research with young children.


Last Modified: 03/06/2024
Modified by: Sudha Arunachalam
